Congratulations and thanks to everyone who participated in the survey. And thanks also to Casa for this donation. If you're making vacation plans, please consider the crypto weekend retreat. I'm teaching with Melvin Demers of Coin shares and also senate hearing, not senate house hearing fame and Dalmak joban Pruja of future perfect ventures. speaker: B

text: Today's guest is Peter van Valkenberg, the director of research at coinsenter. Welcome, Peter.
speaker: A

text: Thanks for having me, Laura.
speaker: C

text: This has been a huge week for cryptocurrency. In the span of a week, we've had the federal reserve chair commenting on bitcoin, the president tweeting about bitcoin cryptocurrencies in libra these house and senate long hearings on libra, which also touched on bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies. What would you say is the significance of all this government activity regarding crypto?
speaker: A

text: Well, so far, nothing, but a lot has yet to be seen. So coin center, where I work, was started five years ago with sort of the explicit goal of educating people about the technology so that if one day something big happened, the response would be reasonable. And what did we mean by big? Whenever we thought about that, we thought, this is money, so it's always possible that someone will use it to do something terrible, like fund terrorism or something like that. So if bitcoin or some cryptocurrency was used in an attack or something, would people react too strongly or would they say, look, this is a tragedy, but we can't blame the sort of purpose, agnostic technologies that people use to maybe support these acts. And there are reasonable good regulations already in. So we were always worried about that black swan event where we'd want educated people in congress and in the agencies to sort of be level headed. But it turns out that the black swan event that got everybody interested in cryptocurrency finally was facebook deciding that they would release what they've occasionally called a cryptocurrency. What I would argue and Meltam in her excellent house testimony yesterday argued is not a cryptocurrency, it's more of a digital currency, like world of warcraft gold or something like that. But that's the significance so far is a lot of people who were sort of maybe we'd briefed a staff member of theirs, or maybe they'd never been briefed at all about it because they just didn't see it as a big part of their basket of issues on the hill or whatever. Suddenly those kinds of people are very interested in cryptocurrency, and the open question is, okay, now that they're interested, what are they going to do?
speaker: C

text: Yeah. And I feel like if I were to write this in a book, I think of the year 2017 as the year that crypto first hit the mainstream, and that after that year, it was kind of a foregone conclusion within the industry that this would be here to stay and wouldn't go away. But then you had this period of this regulatory uncertainty and sort of holding pattern amongst a lot of players in the industry. And so I actually feel like this will be a catalyst to those questions finally being answered and perhaps the industry feeling more confident in how it can move forward. One of the things, though, that I noticed was that in the hearings, it just really struck me how much so many of the lawmakers dislike and distrust facebook. So I just wonder, do you worry or do you think that that aspect could adversely influence the way lawmakers try to regulate the space overall?
speaker: A

text: We do. That was coin center's chief concern, because we're here to represent the underlying technology. We're not here to support or even specifically criticize any project that we think is either good or bad. And our concern with facebook is one the sort of reputational risk that it poses. It's kind of funny for someone who's worked in the bitcoin space to talk about reputational risk from a giant corporation, but I think that's kind of what's going on. But more than the reputational risk, because I think there's plenty of and we saw this in the hearing, there were plenty of people in congress who said, I don't trust you right now because of cambridge analytica or things like that, but I think you're part of a wave of technology in the US. That's generally created jobs and brought prosperity. So I'm not too concerned about people being down on facebook. I think facebook could very well reform its image maybe and be fine. What I'm really concerned about from a cryptocurrency standpoint is sort of the strategy that we've seen unfold from libra, which is know, we are just like bitcoin, we are just like any other cryptocurrency. And so the regulations that would apply to us are the same ones that have been sort of worked out within the bitcoin ethereum space over the last four years. So you see a lot of this maybe not quite as explicitly as I just said, but when you know we're going to have Libra be fully compliant with anti money laundering laws because the on and off ramps of the network will be fully KYC'd and there'd be AML and things like that. That is the standard for sort of how we do AML in the bitcoin space. We don't need KYC information on the blockchain or for a transaction between, say, two software wallets like a casa hodl node and my bread wallet on my iPhone. We don't do KYC there. We do KYC. When you buy bitcoin to basically get onto the network through coinbase, or when you sell bitcoin to get off of the network through, say, I don't know. Kraken now, libra is not like bitcoin in the sense that bitcoin has no one in the middle who could be relied upon to do the KYC. And so it makes sense that there's no regulation of the transactions in the middle from an AML standpoint. There's just miners in between. And they don't have customer relationships. They're not a unified legal entity. They're just people all over the world. Libra has this association in the middle, which at the moment might be 28 companies who've signed letters of intent, and they plan to have about 100 companies like big corporations like visa and mastercard when they launch. That association is something that you could regulate for antimoney laundering purposes. And so this claim that, oh, we'll just do AML KYC at the edges is to a certain extent a claim that we're just like, know, we have to do it at the edges because there's no one in the middle. But that's simply not true the way libra's been described. There's somebody in the middle, somebody really notable, a big group of big legal entities of corporations who are going to keep the blockchain validate transactions, decide what the libre software should look like, all the things that we do in a decentralized way with bitcoin miners and open source software development in the bitcoin space.
speaker: C

text: Yeah, I actually noticed this tension in a few different ways where it seemed like facebook was trying to say, hey, this is one thing, but then later, when answering a different question, the way they would answer that would sort of contradict what they had said earlier. And nathaniel popper released a couple tweets pointing this out as well. I don't remember all of them, but I remember one of them, which we'll actually talk a little bit more about in a actually, no, I remember the first one. It was saying, I guess at one point, David Marcus said, yeah, we won't compete with the dollar. That's not our then, you know, at different points, he was saying, well, we plan to be a global currency. So in that regard those are slightly contradictory. And then another one was him saying we don't intend to be a bank. But then also later on admitting that some of the services they plan to offer in Calibra are maybe lending or investing, that type of thing, which obviously would make them competitive with financial institutions. But one thing that I actually also just wanted to ask you was this point you were making about how it is not like Bitcoin, it is permissioned, it is centralized. So as I was listening to that kind of line of questioning and it kind of was remarkable because I could not help but think oh wow, face libra is what's making some of these lawmakers understand the benefits of something like Bitcoin and other decentralized cryptocurrencies interesting to watch in action. But then I thought, well, if the wind trends in that direction, could we launch something more decentralized? Which I realized was more just like just kind of an imaginative thought. But even disregarding all the issues that raises, I was like whoa. Just even on a pure technical level, a lot of these chains that do have high throughput and scalability are ones that also are more centralized and have few validators. You couldn't do something like this with Ethereum. And then the fact of the matter is too, just the fact that they want it to be backed somehow by some fiat or other stable currencies that's basically like tether which has a lot of issues. Then I started thinking, well, frankly it just feels to me like the way to make this technology go mainstream is that we have to start with a centralized version. Would you agree with that?
speaker: A

text: I think the moment when your grandmother will be using this thing will be the moment when it is super scalable, super easy, the interface doesn't have all this weird crypto jargon inherent in it like private keys and all that and it really is baked into common sense messaging platforms like WhatsApp or Facebook or Signal or whatever. But that's a ways away and I don't think you need centralized cryptocurrencies or digital currencies to ultimately achieve that. If you're willing to be centralized then you already have those things, they're called PayPal. If you're unwilling to be centralized and you want mainstream adoption, you have to build things like the lightning network or plasma on Ethereum. You have to think about Sharding, you have to think maybe about proof of stake or alternative consensus mechanisms. But these are not necessarily things that would end up creating a sort of counterparty or intermediary risk that you get in a normal centralized payment system. So Facebook, I think, with libra, recognized that the decentralized stuff was not ready to suddenly be baked into WhatsApp and thereby allow millions of transactions per day or per hour even per second. And yet they didn't come up with a technological solution that was really capable of maintaining decentralization while providing scalability. And we should forgive them for that because that's really hard. But there are some really exciting projects like Lightning that are starting to actually achieve those results. Now. It's still going to be a number of years until your grandma with a signal app can send Bitcoin seamlessly and without delays or counterparty risk or things like that. But I think we're getting there and I don't think there's a sort of irreconcilable contradiction between decentralization and scalability. It's just harder tech to build. And then the other thing that you were saying about this hearing, finally helping some members of Congress understand Bitcoin and the decentralized technology, I think you're totally you know, I was a bit nervous about these hearings because of the potential collateral consequences, know, distrust of Facebook could give the decentralized space, the Bitcoin space. But these hearings ended up being, just like you suggested, a huge win for explaining exactly what the benefits of these decentralized technologies are to folks in Congress because it was something that and this was also amazing. I don't know if your listeners follow politics much, but these hearings were happening in the backdrop of a really ugly partisan fight that was primarily initiated because of Trump's tweets about whether certain people in Congress should go back to their home countries, which is I'm not even going to wait into any of that. It was all very ugly.
speaker: C

text: And also, let's point out, they're all from the US.
speaker: A

text: Yeah, well, they're all citizens. So a mess and ugly and on both sides, really aggressive partisan rhetoric. And yet despite that happening in the background during these hearings about libra and cryptocurrency, there was actually a shocking amount of bipartisanism. People who were just fighting about this other thing were both agreeing, sometimes for slightly different reasons, that a centralized digital currency like libra presents some somewhat alarming risks. But decentralized cryptocurrencies actually present great opportunities to remove those risks. So I just wanted to point out a couple examples. So from the Democrat side, you had Representative Katie Porter who said, and this is a direct quote, a lot of the concerns I have about libra I do not have about cryptocurrencies. And then she went on a really great line of questioning about libra, says it's backed by dollars. What does backed mean? Does that mean you still own the dollars you gave libra in order to get libra? Or does that mean that they're just always going to have one that matches your libra? What does that even mean when it's a basket of dollars and other currencies versus just a dollar for every libra token? It was a great line of questioning focused on this reserve function, which is something that Bitcoin doesn't have, because a bitcoin is just a bitcoin. It's just a scarce number of items described by the Bitcoin blockchain, and then the demand sense the price. And then Representative Sean Duffy, a Republican, said it was this great moment in the House hearing where he held up a $20 bill. And he said, what's so good about this, Mr. Marcus, is that no one chooses who is allowed to use this $20 bill and who isn't. Whereas with a libra and he's at this point referencing the power of the association in the middle. Just like you censor people on Facebook whose views you don't agree with, you could censor people from using your libra. You are judge and you are jury. And that's fascinating because that brings up the sort of rule of law issues that come up with the fact that there's this middleman, this person that is always going to be the arbiter of whether someone's allowed to transact or buy something or sell something or donate to a political campaign. It's just too much risk to put in one person's hands. And Bitcoin, of course, doesn't have that, because while miners could one off decide not to put a transaction in the block, there's enough of them and they compete with each other with enough vibrancy that you're going to get a transaction in the block. Eventually it's going to happen. None of them have the power to fully and permanently stop you from transacting the way the Libra association, as the essential middleman in keeping the blockchain, would have that power.
speaker: C

text: Back to my conversation with Peter Van Valkenbrick of Coins Center. Yeah, I love what you just said. And actually, it kind of brings us back to one of the points I made earlier, which is actually in a roundabout way, even though the lawmakers really, really distrust Facebook. And my initial question was, oh, could this harm the regulation of the industry? Actually, weirdly, it might give a boost to the industry in the sense that now the lawmakers kind of understand the risks of centralization because they clearly see, oh, we wouldn't want Facebook in charge of I can't remember who it was, but there were others who were saying, like, money is a public good. It shouldn't be something that all of these multinational corporations.
speaker: A

text: I'm not positive if the public good line exactly came from Ocasio Cortez.
speaker: C

text: It might.
speaker: A

text: Or representative cortez or representative talebass.
speaker: C

text: I think it was Alexander Ocasio.
speaker: A

text: People in Congress. And I loved her line of questioning too, because both Representative Ocasio Cortez and Representative Taleb brought up this other big problem of like, okay, who chose who's in the Libra association? And David Marcus came back and said, well, it's an open criteria. You just have to meet the criteria. Of course, that then leads you to ask, like, okay, who set the criteria? And is it really open? At some point, somebody else asked, could a Chinese state owned company that matches the criteria, a billion dollar in assets and a $10 million entry fee, could they join? And there was no clear answer as to whether that was the case. But this line of questioning, like, who is allowed to join the Libra Association? And why were the initial 28 sort of picked the way they were? Is really great for explaining bitcoin as well, because a lot of people have struggled with proof of work as this sort of costly, potentially bad for the environment weird, arbitrary game that people are playing on their computers. In order to mine bitcoin, it doesn't immediately strike someone who's not a crypto native as something that sounds good, but this is exactly what solves the dilemma of who should play this role in the bitcoin space. We don't want to give one corporation the chance to sort of weigh the dice and choose who's in the association of people validating the ledger. We don't want one corporation to do it just merely through fiat or through right. We want there to be a fair and open competition for who gets to do it. And so it needs to be some kind of a lottery. And the only way to make the lottery tickets expensive so that someone can't just buy billions of them and claim to be different people is to have computers do a proof of work calculation or maybe do proof of stake. I don't want to suggest that proof of stake is not a potential viable, open solution to the consensus problem. But no matter what, we just want a fair game to sort of let people rotate playing this important role and that's an amazing innovation, and it's an innovation that goes all the way back to 2008, 2009 with the Satoshi White paper. And finally we can go to someone like Representative Ocasio Cortez and say, you're totally right, you're totally right that it shouldn't be some sort of this person just happened to be rich and powerful and said therefore the ledger will be validated by these people. That's lousy. Instead, it should just be a fair and transparent and open game that people play. And when they play it fairly and honestly, they'll get a chance to be part of the network based on the rules that were set out in the software.
speaker: C

text: So are you trying to set up a meeting with her?
speaker: A

text: I haven't been on this meeting, but we've been in contact with some of her staff.
speaker: C

text: Okay, yeah, because there were just a lot of these moments. So back to Libra. I wanted to ask because you pointed out that it wasn't kind of a predictably partisan line of questioning from either side. So I just wondered, how do you think that aspect will affect I can't even speak the ability of Libra to go forward. Do you think that will yeah, I don't know. Are both sides going to end up against it or yeah, what do you think is going to.
speaker: A

text: Know? I honestly hope that there isn't some sort of so obviously everybody knows that our big issue is we don't want a strong overreaction that would make it impossible to use or run Bitcoin software or something like that. And I'm not too worried about that now, although we still have to be vigilant. But I also just personally hope that there isn't too strong of a reaction to Facebook. I'm not rooting for Facebook to fail or to be regulated into non existence with its Libra product. I don't think that's good for competition or for innovation either. There should be multiple approaches to solving things like financial inclusion and more private financial transactions. Do I think that the Libra project as designed is the best way to achieve those results? No, but I do think they have a right to build it as long as they comply with relevant laws. And I do think that they're entering the field will just cause rival projects to take the challenge up and be serious about competing. And depending on which one you believe in, whether it's Bitcoin or Ethereum or Zcash, I think this is good, this is the right kind of competition that we want. I will say this though, about Libra's chances for success because of the difference in architecture, because of the fact that there is a Libra association that is trusted to validate transactions and always is the gatekeeper between one person. On the network paying another person. And also because they are trusted to keep this reserve fund, which in theory will be balanced in order to keep the libra units stable against the dollar or other international currencies. They're going to have more regulatory challenges than Bitcoin did. And so the two big things to watch out for, I think, are sanctions law, which a few people have talked about. But if anybody can generate a libra address and that's how it's currently specified in the protocol, and some libra addresses end up on the Sdn list, which is a list kept by OFAC the part of the treasury that enforces sanctions law that says, you can't pay someone in Iran, you can't pay someone in North Korea. If some of those Libra addresses end up on that sanctions list, the association is going to have to comply with OFAC. And you might say, okay, well, that sounds fine, they'll just comply with OFAC. But it's going to be this sort of endless whack a mole where more people generate more addresses that are going to end up on the sanctions list and the association is just going to have this massive duty to obey OFAC that I think ultimately will make the network and their ability to create the functionality of the network extremely hard to maintain. Now, maybe they'll find a way to figure that one out, but the fact that there's always this central arbiter of transactions means that that central arbiter is going to have to comply with a mountain of sanctions law issues and a mountain of AML issues, and not just US. Based ones. Like, what if a European member of the association says, we're not a US. Company, we're not subject to U. S. Sanctions, and they put a transaction in the ledger, but then a US. Company says, wait a minute, we can't be in an association with a member who violates sanctions. We can't do that. And this is not just a hypothetical, because right now Europe is finding ways to go around American sanctions against Iran because they disagree with our foreign policy. So it's not an academic discussion at all. It's, I think, foundationally difficult. And then real thing. The other thing on securities law, which I think is maybe just as difficult, is and we saw a lot of the panelists, gary Gensler, former CFTC Chairman, and Meltom demures, both say, look, to me this looks like an ETF, an exchange traded fund. If it is basically a Tokenized ETF or a tokenized money market fund, because they have this reserve and because they actively manage the reserve and decide what should go in the reserve and what should not go in the reserve, then there's this question, all right? The investment tokens that the Libra Association members get, those are definitely securities, and Facebook's been transparent about that because they pay interest from all the money in the reserve. But what about the Libra token itself? Is that really just currency, or is it a claim on the principal rather than the interest in the reserve? And if it's a claim on the principle of a fund, it's probably a security under US law and if it's a security under US law, the libra currency itself, it can only trade on national securities exchanges, it can't trade on Coinbase. And there's all kinds of regulatory compliance issues that would suddenly emerge for any American citizen using libra because it would be the same as an American citizen transacting with stocks and bonds, unlike an American citizen transacting with just a $20 note. So that could be very difficult to comply with and could also be potentially deadly to the project. So I'm not too worried about sweeping overreach from Congress creating difficulties, although it certainly could still happen. But I am worried just about basic compliance with existing law because I think they've got a really hard road ahead of them.
speaker: C

text: Yeah, something that I was thinking about, and I sort of referenced this earlier, is that Facebook, as you mentioned, they kind of want to have it both ways. They want to seem like Bitcoin but frankly they have to go the regulatorily compliant route. Right. And in a way that's probably also why they chose the types of members that they did for the association. But then weirdly, I actually feel like this is probably far fetched but it's just kind of continuing down the trend I mentioned earlier where it seemed like a lot of the lawmakers were kind of understanding the benefits of decentralization. I just wonder if the complications of trying to make Libra compliant with existing regulation will sort of point out the burden I guess that a lot of companies face in this industry and if that maybe could also help spur more friendly regulations which a lot of the industry has been agitating for. Do you think that's likely at all?
speaker: A

text: I think it's possible. I don't know if you're going to get that much sympathy though because there's not much different here from a policy standpoint than what you have with a typical fully centralized regulated entity like PayPal or a bank or something like that. The difference is you've got this quasi decentralization it's a hundred members of an association instead of just us.
speaker: C

text: No, but I mean regulations for truly decentralized cryptocurrencies, do you know what I'm saying?
speaker: A

text: Oh, but they're good. I think the regulations for truly decentralized cryptocurrencies are actually quite good. Right.
speaker: C

text: Mean I guess some of the stuff that you mentioned earlier about OFAC I was going to point out that that already does apply to the Bitcoin blockchain. There are two addresses I believe that have already been absolutely yeah, but the.
speaker: A

text: Fundamental difference here is you can be a miner on the Bitcoin blockchain and you're one of worst case scenario, you're one of maybe ten or 15 powerful miners in the world who sort of take turns keeping the blockchain. And in a better case scenario with things like better hash and a few other innovations that could decentralize mining better, you're maybe one of 40 or 50 or 100 parties that are. Doing this. And so if you're based in the US. You comply with sanctions law, that's just what you do. You look and see if there's bitcoin addresses on the OFAC list, and then you just don't validate transactions to those addresses. But if you're not based in the US. You don't comply with sanctions law. So you don't have that problem where there's this international association that has to comply with the laws of every jurisdiction. Miners just comply with the laws of the jurisdiction that they find themselves in. And the same is true of anti money laundering law, where we can do anti money laundering law at the edges of the network, because there's no single party in the center that could always do it for everybody on the network. And that's currently the policy of Finsen and treasury. And secretary Mnuchin gave a speech about bitcoin and cryptocurrencies in advance of the hearings as well, because as he said, this has been a crazy week. And what secretary Minuchin said was, look, we've got this under control. We've done two big things. We issued new guidance in 2019, and by the way, that's guidance that says that software developers are not regulated for anti money laundering purposes. Even multi SIG providers with a minority number of keys are not regulated. Custodial exchanges are regulated, the edges of the network. And the other thing he said that we did is export US. Rules to the fatif, which will export them internationally, because the fatif is the international body that tells other countries how to do their AML. So we've actually ended up in this great place from an AML standpoint for bitcoin, where we know who's regulated the custodial exchanges and wallet providers and no one else on the network. Libra, you could argue, well, it should be just the same. It's just the custodial exchanges and wallet providers like Calibra, the wholly owned Facebook subsidiary. But it's hard to argue that when there's also this libra association right in the middle of the network with a perfect vantage point to do all the AML for the entire network. And when it's made up of legal corporations and other regulated entities who could very easily be relied upon by people in government to stop illicit flows of funds and things like, you know, miners all over the world. It's just not as feasible to actually put that kind of compliance burden on all of them, because most of them aren't even us. Based companies. They might even just be individuals.
speaker: C

text: Right, well, one other thing that I wanted to ask was, do you think that kind of seeing this threat from libra that that could spur the US. Government to more quickly act on a central bank digital currency?
speaker: A

text: The big problem with central bank digital currencies, especially from the US. Standpoint, I'll just give a really quick thesis. This is not my area of expertise, but this is a pretty strongly held belief of my own, is that they're just not ever going to be viable anytime soon. Because if a central bank issues directly into American wallets, digital wallets, americans would have no reason to keep their money in banks. Because why would you take the risk of keeping your money in the bank when you can have direct to central bank money in your pocket? And so it would be massively disruptive to the banking sector if the central bank issued a digital currency because it would basically obviate the need for bank deposits and lending and it would completely change monetary policy in the US. Because know, we used to use interest rates for lending to try and control the monetary supply. And now the Fed can still do that, sort of. But way better for them to just create or destroy units and give. Them directly to American citizens in a digital wallet, or maybe even directly delete them from the wallets of American citizens in a sort of negative interest rate type scheme. This is all Sci-Fi and the fed is a member association of banks. They're not going to put themselves out of business.
speaker: C

text: Yeah, well one other thing I want to ask about, this is also kind of an unlikely scenario I wanted to talk about, but it was that draft bill to prevent tech companies from creating cryptocurrencies. How likely is that to go anywhere?
speaker: A

text: So it's hard to really develop sort of like odds or percentage of success? Likelihood because things are very chaotic right now and things are very uncertain both from a partisanship standpoint which would generally make you think that nothing's going to pass unless it's totally bipartisan. But as I was just saying, there's a surprising amount of bipartisanship around people being wary of Facebook and wary of it launching a cryptocurrency. I think the collateral consequences of the keep big tech out of finance act that Maxine Waters presented might be severe enough that it ends up being something that cooler heads, maybe even maxine Waters herself decide needs to be moderated a bit because basically that law says you can't even run a money services business. So products like Google wallet or Apple Pay would have to be shut down. So that seems a little extreme. Although I don't know, let me just give my disclaimer again. This is not coin center's issue area because we don't represent any of big tech, we don't want to represent any of big tech. We want to represent open source protocols for cryptocurrency. But the one thing I will say about that proposal, not that I advocate for it at all because again I think everybody should be allowed to compete in this space and I don't think we need laws to protect bitcoin from big corporation competition because I don't think they can actually compete on the margins where we're succeeding. But at the very least that law wouldn't hurt bitcoin, wouldn't make a hostile regulatory environment for bitcoin or ethereum, not that it's necessarily good for innovation or anything else, but at least it's a calibrated response, not a response that we were originally afraid of, which was something like all cryptocurrencies are banned, or something like that.
speaker: C

text: Right. All right, so I guess just the last question before we sign off. I just was curious. So you did mention that you felt that the way Libra is constructed, it is kind of like an ETF. And in the hearings, David Marcus seemed not to really know who the regulator or regulators should be for Libra. So which government agencies do you think should regulate Libra?

text: It's really not for me to say. I think it's already clear. Or maybe they can even make the argument that, yeah, it's a lot like an ETF, but because users don't expect profits and David Marcus did say this in the hearings, because they don't expect profits from something that is meant to be stable, it shouldn't be regulated as a security.
